docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional budget hawks have turned their attention to the Class Act, the nation’s first government-run long-term care insurance system. The program’s supporters and advocates, including more than 250 organizations representing older adults and people with disabilities, have fretted for some time about its fate, fearing that the Republican-controlled House of Representatives might try to dismantle it before it could take effect next year.

headline.main: The Class Act in the Crosshairs

docs.abstract: The Senate’s so-called Gang of Six are pushing for repeal of the first government-run insurance program for long-term care, set to begin next year.
docs.snippet: The Senate’s so-called Gang of Six are pushing for repeal of the first government-run insurance program for long-term care, set to begin next year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senfronia Thompson has spent nearly 40 years in the Texas State House of Representatives fighting for the underserved, so her close ties to certain industries seem out of character.

headline.seo: A Texas Representative Plays Both Sides
headline.main: Defending ‘Little Dogs’ but Playing Both Sides
headline.print_headline: Defending ‘Little Dogs’ But Playing Both Sides

docs.snippet: Senfronia Thompson has spent nearly 40 years in the Texas State House of Representatives fighting for the underserved, so her close ties to certain industries seem out of character.

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials said that President Obama and the House speaker, John A. Boehner, were closing in on a package calling for as much as $3 trillion in savings.

headline.seo: Obama and Boehner Close In on Deal to Cut Debt Nearly $3 Trillion
headline.main: Boehner and Obama Nearing Deal on Cuts and Taxes
headline.print_headline: Obama Closes In On Deal For Cuts In Boehner Talks

docs.snippet: Officials said that President Obama and the House speaker, John A. Boehner, were closing in on a package calling for as much as $3 trillion in savings.

byline.original: By CARL HULSE and JACKIE CALMES
